{{other people5|Gervasius (disambiguation)|Protasius (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox saint |name=Saints Gervasius and Protasius |birth_date= |death_date=2nd century [[AD]] |feast_day=19 June ([[Catholic Church]])
14 October ([[Eastern Orthodox Church]]) |venerated_in=[[Roman Catholic Church]]; [[Eastern Orthodox Church]] |image=Gervaseandprotase.jpg |caption="''The martyrdom of Saints Gervase and Protase''," from a 14th-century manuscript. |birth_place=[[Milan]] |death_place=[[Milan]] |titles=Martyrs |beatified_date= |beatified_place= |beatified_by= |canonized_date= |canonized_place= |canonized_by= |attributes=the [[scourge]], the [[Club (weapon)|club]] and the [[sword]] |patronage=[[Milan]]; [[Breisach]]; [[hay]]makers; invoked for the discovery of thieves |major_shrine=[[Basilica Sant'Ambrogio]], [[Milan]], [[Italy]] |suppressed_date= |issues= }} '''Saints Gervasius and Protasius''' (also '''Saints Gervase and Protase''', '''Gervasis and Prothasis''' and in [[French (language)|French]] ''Gervais and Protais'') are venerated as [[Christian martyrs]], probably of the 2nd century. They are the [[patron saints]] of [[Milan]] and of [[hay]]makers and are invoked for the discovery of thieves. Their [[feast day]] in the Latin Rite of the [[Catholic Church]] is 19 June, the day marking the [[translation (relics)|translation]] of their relics. In the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]] and in the Eastern Rites of the [[Catholic Church]], their feast takes place on 14 October ([[Adoption of the Gregorian calendar#Adoption in Eastern Europe|O.S.]])/24 October ([[Adoption of the Gregorian calendar#Adoption in Eastern Europe|N.S.]]), the traditional day of their death. In Christian [[iconography]] their emblems are the scourge, the club and the sword. ==Legend== The ''[[Acta Sanctorum|acta]]''"Acta Sanctorum" June, IV, 680 and 29. may have been expanded from a letter (''Epistle'' liii) to the bishops of [[Italy]], falsely ascribed to [[Saint Ambrose]]. They are written in a very simple style; it has not been possible to establish the date of their composition. According to these, Gervasius and Protasius were the twin sons of martyrs. Their father, [[Vitalis of Milan|Saint Vitalis of Milan]], a man of consular dignity, suffered martyrdom at [[Ravenna]], possibly under [[Nero]]. Their mother, [[Saint Valeria]], died for her faith at Milan. Gervasius and Protasius were imprisoned, and visited in prison by [[Nazarius and Celsus|Saint Nazarius]]. The sons are said to have large hands and had been scourged and then beheaded, during the reign of the Emperor [[Nero]], under the presidency of Anubinus or Astasius, and while Caius was [[Bishop of Milan]]. Some authors place the martyrdom under the Emperor [[Diocletian]], but others object to this time, because it is not clear how, in that case, the place of burial, and even the names, could be forgotten by the time of Saint Ambrose, as is stated. It probably occurred during the reign of Emperor [[Marcus Aurelius]] (161-180).[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/06537a.htm Mershman, Francis. "Sts. Gervasius and Protasius." The Catholic Encyclopedia. Vol. 6. New York: Robert Appleton Company, 1909. 24 Jan. 2014] ==Ambrose and Saints Gervasius and Protasius== [[Image:Philippe de Champaigne SS Gervase and Protase.jpg|thumb|left|Gervasius and Protasius, by [[Philippe de Champaigne]]]] [[Saint Ambrose]], in 386, had built a magnificent [[basilica]] at Milan, now called the [[Basilica Sant'Ambrogio]]. Asked by the people to consecrate it in the same solemn manner as was done in [[Rome]], he promised to do so if he could obtain the necessary relics. In a dream, he was shown the place where such relics could be found. He ordered excavations to be made outside the city, in the cemetery Church of [[Nabor and Felix|Saints Nabor and Felix]], who were at the time the primary patrons of Milan, and there found the relics of Saints Gervasius and Protasius. In a letter, St Ambrose wrote: ''"I found the fitting signs, and on bringing in some on whom hands were to be laid, the power of the holy martyrs became so manifest, that even whilst I was still silent, one was seized and thrown prostrate at the holy burial-place. We found two men of marvelous stature, such as those of ancient days. All the bones were perfect, and there was much blood."''[http://urban.hunter.cuny.edu/~thead/gervase.htm Letter of St. Ambrose of Milan on the discovery of the Relics of Sts. Gervasius and Protasius] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516012528/http://urban.hunter.cuny.edu/~thead/gervase.htm |date=2008-05-16 }} St Ambrose had their relics removed to the Basilica of Fausta (now the Church of [[Saints Vitalis and Agricola]]),[http://urban.hunter.cuny.edu/~thead/gervase.htm Letter of Ambrose of Milan on the] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516012528/http://urban.hunter.cuny.edu/~thead/gervase.htm |date=2008-05-16 }} and on the next day into the basilica, accompanied in the texts by many miracles, emblematic of divine favor in the context of the great struggle then taking place between St Ambrose and the [[Arianism|Arian]] Empress [[Justina (empress)|Justina]].D. H. Williams, "Ambrose of Milan and the End of the Arian-Nicene Conflicts," Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1995 discusses the "inventio" and "depositio" of the relics as thecrowning gesture of Ambrose's triumph over the Arians. Of the vision, the subsequent discovery of the relics and the accompanying miracles, St Ambrose wrote to his sister Marcellina. [[Saint Augustine]], not yet baptized, witnessed these facts, and relates them in his ''"Confessions"'' (IX, vii), and in ''"De Civitate Dei"'' (XXII, viii) as well as in his ''"Sermon 286 in natal. Ss. Mm. Gerv. et Prot."''. They are also attested by [[Paulinus of Nola|Saint Paulinus]] in his life of Saint Ambrose. The latter died in 397 and by his own wish was buried in his basilica by the side of these martyrs. It has been suggested that the [[Brescia Casket]] was made for or used to hold the relics. ==Veneration== [[Image:Sant'Ambrogio Cript in Basilica of Sant'Ambrogio, Milan.jpg|thumb|left|The crypt in [[Basilica Sant'Ambrogio|Sant'Ambrogio]] basilica. Embossed silver urn, displaying the skeletons of [[Saint Ambrose|Saints Ambrose]], Gervase, and Protase.]] J. Rendel Harris, in ''"The Dioscuri in the Christian Legends"'' (London, 1903), addressed the subject of twin saints in Christian legend, who seem to be connected with the [[Dioscuri]], whose cult was tenacious, surmised from an oration decrying their veneration by [[Dio Chrystostom]] (''"Orations"'' 61.11). The historicity of Gervasius and Protasius was defended in the ''"Analecta Bollandist."'' (1904), XXIII, 427. Immediately after the discovery of the relics by Saint Ambrose, the [[Cult (religious practice)|cult]] of Saints Gervasius and Protasius was spread in Italy, and churches were built in their honor at [[Pavia]], [[Nola]] and other places. In [[Gaul]] (modern-day [[France]]), about 400{{citation needed|date=November 2015}} churches were dedicated to them, at [[Le Mans|Mans]], [[Rouen]] and [[Soissons]]. At the [[Louvre]] in [[Paris]], there is now a famous picture of the saints by [[Eustache Le Sueur|Lesueur]] (d. 1655), which was formerly in their church at [[Paris]]. According to the ''"[[Liber Pontificalis]],"'' [[Pope Innocent I]] (402-417) dedicated a church to them at Rome. Later, the name of [[Vitalis of Milan|St Vitalis]], their father, was added to the title of this church ([[Basilica of San Vitale (Rome)|Basilica of San Vitale]]). Very early on, their names were inserted into the [[Litany of the Saints]]. In 835, Angilbert II, [[Bishop of Milan]], placed the relics of the three saints in a [[Porphyry (geology)|porphyry]] [[sarcophagus]], where they were found in January 1864.''Civiltà Cattolica'', 1864, IX, 608, and XII, 345 A tradition claims that, after the destruction of Milan by [[Frederick Barbarossa]], his chancellor, [[Rainald of Dassel]], had taken the relics from Milan and deposited them at [[Breisach]] in [[Germany]], whence some came to [[Soissons]]. The claim is rejected by Milan.Biraghi, ''Civiltà Cattolica'', 1864, IX, 608, and XII, 345. Nevertheless, they were [[venerated]] by farmers in Germany and a German saying amongst harvesters was: ''"Wenn's regnet auf Gervasius / es vierzig Tage regnen muss"'' (''"When it rains on St Gervasius' Day / forty days of rain will follow"'').[http://www.heiligenlexikon.de/BiographienG/Gervasius.htm Gervasius - Ökumenisches Heiligenlexikon] Thus, as with the cults of [[Swithun|Saint Swithun]], [[Saint Medard]], the [[Seven Sleepers]], and [[Saint Godelieve]], that of Sts Gervasius and Protasius was connected with the weather. A famous series of [[tapestry|tapestries]] of the ''"Life of Gervasius and Protasius,"'' donated to the [[Cathedral of Our Lady (Antwerp)|Cathedral of Antwerp]] in 1509, is displayed in the cathedral's choir.Laura Weigert, "Reconstructing Medieval Pictorial Narrative: Louis Joubert's Tapestry Restoration Project" ''Art Journal'' '''54'''.2, Conservation and Art History, Summer 1995:67-72. ==See also== *[[Kantheesangal]] *[[St-Gervais-et-St-Protais Church]] *[[San Gervasio (disambiguation)]] *[[San Trovaso]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== * [[Saint Ambrose|Ambrose]], ed. & tr. by John Hugo Wolfgang Gideon Liebeschuetz, [https://books.google.com/books?id=_qQsA7gE6UoC&pg=PA200&lpg=PA200&dq ''Ambrose Of Milan: Political Letters And Speeches'' (google preview)], 2005, Liverpool University Press, {{ISBN|0853238294}}, 9780853238294; full text [http://www.fordham.edu/halsall/source/ambrose-letter22.asp Ambrose of Milan: Letter 22: ''The Finding of SS. Gervasius and Protasius''], Fordham *{{Catholic|wstitle=Sts. Gervasius and Protasius}} ==External links== {{commons category multi|Saint Gervasius|Saint Protasius}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071013150803/http://catholic-forum.com/saints/saintg29.htm Gervase] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071109161002/http://www.catholic-forum.com/saints/saintp45.htm Protase] *[http://www.christianiconography.info/gervaseProtasius.html Saints Gervasius and Protasius] at the [http://www.christianiconography.info Christian Iconography] web site. *[http://www.christianiconography.info/goldenLegend/gervaseProtasius.htm Here Follow the Lives of Saints Gervase and Prothase] from Caxton's translation of the Golden Legend *[http://www.stpetersbasilica.info/Exterior/Colonnades/Saints/St%20Gervase-69/StGervasius.htm St Gervase Colonnade Statue in St Peter's Square] *[http://www.stpetersbasilica.info/Exterior/Colonnades/Saints/St%20Protase-68/StProtasius.htm St Protase Colonnade Statue in St Peter's Square] *{{it icon}} [http://www.santiebeati.it/dettaglio/58350 Santi Gervasio e Protasio] *{{de icon}} [http://www.heiligenlexikon.de/BiographienG/Gervasius.htm Ökumenisches Heiligenlexikon über Gervasius] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gervasius And Protasius}} [[Category:2nd-century deaths]] [[Category:2nd-century Christian martyrs]] [[Category:Burials at the Basilica of Sant'Ambrogio]] [[Category:Saints from Roman Italy]] [[Category:Twin people]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Year of death unknown]] [[Category:Saints duos]]

{{COI|date=June 2011}} {{Infobox person | | name = Hans Zomer | birth_place = [[Leiden]], [[Netherlands]] | occupation = Director of [[Dóchas]] | }}
'''Hans Zomer''' (born 1968) is Director of [[Dóchas]], the Irish national platform of Development NGOs.
Hans became the first Director of Dóchas in 2002, and has chaired the network's major public campaigns, including the [[Make Poverty History]] Irish Campaign, and the "[http://www.actnow2015.ie Act Now on 2015]" campaign.
Prior to his appointment, he worked for [[Concern Worldwide]], one of the largest [[Republic of Ireland|Irish]] [[NGOs]], and as a Development Consultant in [[Pakistan]] and as Coordinator for EIRENE-Tchad, an organisation running human rights and rural development programmes in [[Chad]].
He has wide-ranging experience in NGO networking and advocacy work, having worked for several Brussels-based NGO networks, such as the EU-NGO Liaison Committee (CONCORD’s predecessor) and APRODEV. He is a political scientist by training, having studied in [[Amsterdam]] and [[Copenhagen]], and speaks 5 European languages. He is married with three children.

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Use British English|date=August 2016}} {{For|other persons|Henry Neville (disambiguation){{!}}Henry Neville}} [[File:Henry Neville..jpg|thumb|right|Henry Neville]] '''Thomas Henry Gartside Neville''' (20 June 1837 – 19 June 1910) was an English actor, dramatist, teacher and [[Actor-manager|theatre manager]]. He began his career playing dashing juvenile leads, later specialising in Shakespearean roles, modern comedy and melodrama. His most famous role was as Bob Brierley in [[Tom Taylor]]'s ''[[The Ticket-of-Leave Man (play)|The Ticket-of-Leave Man]]''. As the manager of the [[Olympic Theatre]] from 1873 to 1879, he presented numerous successful productions. In later years, he became a respected character actor.
==Biography==
===Early years=== Neville was born in [[Manchester]], England, son of John Garside Neville and his second wife Mary Anna, ''née'' Gartside (died 1895).<ref name=who>[http://www.ukwhoswho.com/view/article/oupww/whowaswho/U189379 "Neville, Thomas Henry Gartside (Henry Neville)",] ''Who Was Who'', A & C Black, 1920–2008, online edn, Oxford University Press, December 2007, accessed 22 May 2009</ref> He was the twentieth child of his father, an actor and the manager of Queen's Theatre, Spring Gardens, Manchester, who himself was the twentieth child of ''his'' father.<ref name=times>''The Times'', obituary notice, 21 June 1910, p. 13</ref> Though Neville senior was in the theatre, there were strong military traditions on both sides of the family, and John Neville was opposed to his son's decision to pursue a theatrical rather than a military career and refused to help him.<ref name=dnb>Lawrence, W. J. [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/35204 "Neville, (Thomas) Henry Gartside (1837–1910)"], rev. Nilanjana Banerji, ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press, 2004, accessed 22 May 2009</ref> Neville had one brother, George (born c. 1839), one sister, Josaphine (c. 1838–1895), and nineteen half-brothers and sisters.<ref>Collins, Barry. [http://users.zoominternet.net/~bcollins/preview_190.htm "Henry Neville"], Gartside–Neville family website, 2007, accessed 25 May 2009</ref>
[[file:No Thoroughfare by Dickens and Wilkie Collins.jpg|thumb|left|270px|''[[No Thoroughfare]]'' (1868) by [[Charles Dickens]] and [[Wilkie Collins]]. Neville is third from left.]] From 1857 to 1860 Neville acted in the English provinces and Scotland. When the tragedian John Vandenhoff made his farewell performance in 1858 at the Theatre Royal, [[Liverpool]], Neville played Cromwell to Vandenhoff's Wolsey in [[Shakespeare]]'s ''[[Henry VIII (play)|King Henry VIII]]''.<ref name=dnb/> He made his London debut in 1860 as Percy Ardent in [[Dion Boucicault]]'s ''The Irish Heiress'' at the [[Lyceum Theatre, London|Lyceum Theatre]]. ''[[The Observer]]'' said of his performance: "Mr Henry Neville, a new importation from Liverpool, was gentlemanly and easy, of good manners and dashing appearance; and he promises to fill a dreary gap in the London theatrical world – the line of ''jeunes premières''."<ref>''The Observer'', 14 October 1860, p. 2</ref> He attracted further good notices for his next role, in ''The Love Chase'', receiving encouragement from ''The Times'' "as a representative of young men of something like rank and position."<ref>''The Times'', 20 October 1860, p. 9</ref> The same year, he played Victor Savignie in ''Arrienne'' at the Lyceum and, at the [[Olympic Theatre]], he played Ivan in ''Serf'' and Valjean in an adaptation of ''[[Les Miserables]]''.<ref name=perfs>Collins, Barry. [http://users.zoominternet.net/~bcollins/preview_198.htm "Thomas Henry Gartside Neville Performances"], Gartside–Neville family website, 2007, accessed 25 May 2009</ref>
In May 1863, still at the Olympic, Neville created the role of Bob Brierley in [[Tom Taylor]]'s drama about the dismal life of a released convict, ''[[The Ticket-of-Leave Man (play)|The Ticket-of-Leave Man]]'', a character in which he made the success of his career. He played in its long first run and revivals for a total of about 2000 performances.<ref name=dnb/> In 1865, he played the title role in Taylor's ''Henry Dunbar'' at the Olympic opposite [[Kate Terry]],<ref>''The Times'', 21 November 1877, p. 8</ref> and in 1867 was her chosen Romeo to her Juliet in her farewell London performances at the [[Adelphi Theatre]].<ref>''The Times'', 2 September 1867, p. 7</ref> 1867 had been a busy year for Neville at the Adelphi, where he played Job Arnroyd in ''Lost in London'', Benedick in ''[[Much Ado About Nothing]]'', Dunbar again, Farmer Allan in ''Dora'', Richard Watt in ''His First Champagne'', Claude Meinotee in ''Lady of Lyons'', Walter Maidenblush in ''Little Treasure'', Sir Thomas Clifford in ''Hunchback'', and George Vendale in ''[[No Thoroughfare]]'', another notable success.<ref name=perfs/> The next year at the Adelphi, he played the title role in ''[[Hamlet]]'' and repeated Robert Brierley. In 1869, still at the Adelphi, he portrayed the role of Vernon Wainwright in ''Eve''.<ref name=perfs/> At the [[Gaiety Theatre, London|Gaiety Theatre]] in the same year, he played an important role in [[W. S. Gilbert]]'s early comedy, ''[[An Old Score]]''.<ref name=dnb/>
===Actor-manager=== [[File:TicketFarrenBarrington.jpg|left|thumb|upright|1875 Revival of ''The Ticket-of-Leave Man'', starring Neville and [[Nellie Farren]]]] Neville continued building his reputation on the London stage in the 1870s as actor and also as the manager of the Olympic Theatre from 1873 to 1879, where his company included rising actors such as [[Rutland Barrington]], [[Helen Ernstone]], [[Emily Fowler]] and [[Johnston Forbes-Robertson]].<ref>[http://www-unix.oit.umass.edu/~a0fs000/1800/0409.html The Olympic Theatre: Static Information - list of managers], accessed 21 May 2009</ref><ref>''The Times'', 6 July 1877, p. 42; and 4 September 1878, p. 3</ref> In 1870, he played Henry Little in ''Put Yourself in His Place'' at the Adelphi.<ref name=perfs/> In 1872 he had a great success in ''[[The School for Scandal]]'' of which ''The Times'' said, "Mr Henry Neville is the leading actor in the class of characters in which Charles Surface is comprised."<ref>''The Times'', 12 November 1872, p. 5</ref> This was followed, at the Olympic, by ''The School for Intrigue'', in which he played the part of Almaviva.<ref name=perfs/> Other successes during the 1870s, both as manager and actor, included his portrayal of Lord Clancarty in Taylor's ''Lady Clancarty'', Pierre in [[John Oxenford]]'s ''The Two Orphans'' in 1874, an 1874–75 revival of ''The Ticket-of-Leave Man'', and Franklin Blake in a dramatisation of [[Wilkie Collins]]'s ''[[The Moonstone]]'' in 1877.<ref name=dnb/> In the same year he produced and starred in a revival of ''Lady Audley's Secret'' by Robert Walters.<ref>''The Times'', 6 July 1877, p. 4</ref> He also produced [[W. S. Gilbert]]'s plays ''[[The Ne'er-do-Weel]]'' in 1878 and ''[[Gretchen (play)|Gretchen]]'' in 1879.<ref>''The Times'', 24 March 1879, p. 10</ref>
[[File:LONDON ILLUSTR(1877) p6.137 HENRY NEVILLE.jpg|thumbnail|Henry Neville (1877)]] In 1878, Neville opened a successful drama school which he managed for many years.<ref>The ODNB gives the date as 1878, but Neville's own entry in ''Who's Who'' gives the year as 1884</ref> By the 1880s, he had become famous in [[melodrama]] roles, playing the romantic lead. His Shakespeare roles included Jaques in ''[[As You Like It]]'', produced by Madame Modjeska (1882) and Leonato in ''Much Ado About Nothing''. In 1888, he played Count Heidegger in ''Handsome Is that Handsome Does'', a comedy by C. J. Ribton Turner at the [[Vaudeville Theatre]].<ref>''The Times'', 6 June 1888, p. 10</ref> At the Olympic that year, he reprised the role Pierre in ''The Two Orphans'' and appeared in ''Hands Across the Sea'' by Henry Pettitt.<ref>''The Times'', 25 January 1889, p. 9</ref>
===Later years=== In 1890, Neville went to America with [[Augustus Harris]]'s company, appearing for 200 nights as Captain Temple in ''Human Nature'', renamed ''The Soudan'' for its U.S. production. On his return to England he resumed his successful place in the autumn melodramas at the [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]].<ref name=dnb/>
The last phase of Neville's career was with [[Beerbohm Tree|Herbert Beerbohm Tree's]] company at [[Her Majesty's Theatre|His Majesty's Theatre]], where his roles included Leonato<ref>''The Times'', 25 January 1905, p. 10</ref> and, in ''[[Richard II (play)|Richard II]]'', John of Gaunt.<ref>''The Times'', 25 April 1905, p. 3</ref> His last engagement was in Tree's revival of ''The School for Scandal'' in 1909. By this stage in his career, Neville had moved to the role of Sir Oliver Surface, with Robert Loraine in Neville's old role as Sir Oliver's nephew, Charles. ''[[The Manchester Guardian]]'' found Neville "admirably sonorous" in the part.<ref>''The Manchester Guardian'', 8 April 1909. p. 7</ref> ''The Observer'' wrote: "the weighty Sir Oliver of Mr Henry Neville, so well remembered as the dashing Charles Surface of thirty years ago, is exactly in tune with the quietly humorous Moses of Mr [[Lionel Brough]]".<ref>''The Observer'', 11 April 1909. p. 5</ref>
Neville wrote six plays, all melodramas. He also published some short books on the theatre, entitled ''The Stage, its Past and Present, in Relation to Fine Art''; ''Gesture; Her First Appearance''; and ''His First and Last Benefit,''<ref name=who/>
Neville died at [[Seaford, East Sussex|Seaford]], [[Sussex]], one day short of his 73rd birthday, of a heart attack induced by a minor accident and was buried at Christ Church in [[Denshaw]], [[Saddleworth]], [[Yorkshire]].<ref name=times/> He left four sons, from his marriage to Harriet Jane Waddell (c. 1837–1903).<ref name=who/><ref>Collins, Barry. [http://users.zoominternet.net/~bcollins/preview_200.htm "Thomas Henry Gartside & Harriet Jane Neville Family (A)"], Gartside–Neville family website, 2007, accessed 25 May 2009</ref> ''The Times'' concluded its obituary notice of Neville: "He had troops of friends, and there are not two opinions as to his reputation for fair dealing with his fellow men. As well as an actor, he was a man of business, with a fund of common sense, fond of sport, and a glutton for outdoor exercise. He was well known as a [[Freemason]] and generally respected by all with whom he was associated, and beloved by those who knew him intimately."<ref name=times/>

''The History of the Boston Theatre 1854-1901''] * [http://shakespeare.emory.edu/actordisplay.cfm?actorid=283 "Henry Neville (1837-1910)"] at Shakespeare and the Players * [https://books.google.com/books?id=5AQ71r_JC6YC&pg=PA98&lpg=PA98&dq=Henry+Neville+Olympic+Brierly+taylor&source=bl&ots=I3GiTSWp4Y&sig=z4nzWInWnexuEFDTZoyvFtvx8-A&hl=en&ei=Gu0WSo6mIca-lAeAnZHWCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5#PPA98-IA1,M1 Information about Neville and photo as Bob Brierly] *[http://users.zoominternet.net/~bcollins/preview_189.htm Photo of Neville] *[http://users.zoominternet.net/~bcollins/preview_204.htm More photos of Neville] *[https://archive.org/details/stageitspastpres00nevirich "The Stage: Its Past and Present in Relation to Fine Art", by Henry Neville, 1875]

[[File:Jared Leto, San Diego Comic Con 2016 (2).jpg|200px|thumbnail|right|alt=A profile picture of an adult man.|Leto at the 2016 [[San Diego Comic-Con International]]]] [[Jared Leto]] is an American entertainer with an extensive career in film, music, and television. He made his debut with minor roles in the television shows ''[[Camp Wilder]]'' (1992) and ''[[The Torkelsons#Almost Home|Almost Home]]'' (1993). He achieved recognition in 1994 for his role as Jordan Catalano in the [[teen drama]] television series ''[[My So-Called Life]]''.{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/entertainment/the-big-interview-30-seconds-to-mars-frontman-jared-leto-26347148.html|title=The Big Interview: 30 Seconds to Mars frontman Jared Leto|first=John|last=Meagher|date=January 25, 2008|work=[[Irish Independent]]|accessdate=June 14, 2011}} The show was praised for its portrayal of adolescence and gained a [[cult following]], despite being canceled after only one season.{{cite book|last=Lavery|first=David|title=The Essential Cult TV Reader|year=2010|publisher=University Press of Kentucky|location=Lexington|isbn=978-0-8131-2568-8|page=174}} The same year, he made his television film debut starring alongside [[Alicia Silverstone]] in ''[[Cool and the Crazy]]''. Leto's first film role was in the 1995 drama ''[[How to Make an American Quilt]]''. He later co-starred with [[Christina Ricci]] in ''[[The Last of the High Kings]]'' (1996) and received a supporting role in ''[[Switchback (film)|Switchback]]'' (1997). In 1997, Leto starred in the biopic ''[[Prefontaine (film)|Prefontaine]]'' in which he played the role of Olympic hopeful [[Steve Prefontaine]]. His portrayal received positive reviews from critics and is often considered his breakthrough role.{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/1997/film/reviews/prefontaine-1117432640/|title=Prefontaine|first=Todd|last=McCarthy|date=February 1, 1997|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=June 14, 2011}}{{cite journal|date=September 28, 1998|title=His So-Called Life's on a Roll|first=Louis B.|last=Hobson|journal=Calgary Sun}} The following year, Leto starred together with [[Alicia Witt]] in the horror ''[[Urban Legend (film)|Urban Legend]]''. He then acted alongside [[Sean Penn]] and [[Adrien Brody]] in the war film ''[[The Thin Red Line (1998 film)|The Thin Red Line]]'' (1998). After playing supporting roles in ''[[Black and White (1999 drama film)|Black and White]]'' and ''[[Girl, Interrupted (film)|Girl, Interrupted]]'', Leto portrayed Angel Face in ''[[Fight Club]]'' (1999), which has since became a [[cult film]].{{cite journal|last=Ansen|first=David|date=July 11, 2005|title=Is Anybody Making Movies We'll Actually Watch In 50 Years?|journal=Newsweek}} In 2000, Leto played Paul Allen in the psychological thriller ''[[American Psycho (film)|American Psycho]]''. The same year, he starred as heroin addict Harry Goldfarb in ''[[Requiem for a Dream]]'', directed by [[Darren Aronofsky]]. His acting in the addiction drama received praise from film critics.{{cite web|url=http://movieline.com/2002/04/01/jared-leto-thriving-in-the-dark/|title=Jared Leto: Thriving in the Dark|first=Dennis|last=Hensley|date=April 1, 2002|work=[[Movieline]]|accessdate=December 7, 2013}} During this period Leto focused increasingly on his band [[Thirty Seconds to Mars]], returning to acting in 2002 in the [[David Fincher]]-directed thriller ''[[Panic Room]]'', which was well-received both critically and commercially.{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/panic_room/|title=Panic Room (2002)|publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]. [[Flixster]]|accessdate=December 7, 2013}}{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/3575916/Not-just-a-pretty-face.html|title=Not just a pretty face|first=Emma|last=Forrest|date=April 13, 2002|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=December 7, 2013}} Following the lead role in the independent film, ''[[Highway (2002 film)|Highway]]'' (2002), he co-starred with [[Colin Farrell]] in the historical drama ''[[Alexander (2004 film)|Alexander]]'' (2004) as [[Hephaestion]]. Leto then starred together with [[Nicolas Cage]] in the political crime thriller ''[[Lord of War]]'' (2005) and acted alongside [[Salma Hayek]] in the crime drama ''[[Lonely Hearts (2006 film)|Lonely Hearts]]'' (2006) as [[Raymond Fernandez]]. He also began to direct music videos for Thirty Seconds to Mars, with the first being "[[The Kill]]" (2006). The following year, he portrayed [[Mark David Chapman]] in the biopic ''[[Chapter 27]]''. Despite divided critical opinion on the film as a whole, Leto's performance was widely praised.{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/default/article/Film-clips-3217575.php#page-2|title=Chapter 27|first=Joel|last=Selvin|date=April 18, 2008|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|accessdate=September 30, 2011}} In 2009, he starred in the science fiction drama ''[[Mr. Nobody (film)|Mr. Nobody]]'' directed by [[Jaco Van Dormael]]. Critics praised the film's artistry and Leto's acting.{{cite news|title=L’extra (et) ordinaire Mister Nobody|first=Nicolas|last=Crousse|work=[[Le Soir]]|url=http://www.lesoir.be/archives?url=/culture/cinema/2010-01-13/l-extra-et-ordinaire-mister-nobody-748326.php|date=January 13, 2010|accessdate=December 7, 2013|language=French|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131220023410/http://www.lesoir.be/archives?url=%2Fculture%2Fcinema%2F2010-01-13%2Fl-extra-et-ordinaire-mister-nobody-748326.php|archivedate=December 20, 2013|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Movies/Reviews/M/Mr_Nobody/2010/07/15/14722401.html|title=‘Mr. Nobody’ something special|first=Bruce|last=Kirkland|publisher=[[Jam!]]. [[Canoe.ca]]|date=July 15, 2010|accessdate=July 3, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120711205751/http://jam.canoe.ca/Movies/Reviews/M/Mr_Nobody/2010/07/15/14722401.html|archivedate=July 11, 2012|df=}} He later directed the music videos for "[[Kings and Queens (Thirty Seconds to Mars song)|Kings and Queens]]" (2009) and "[[Hurricane (Thirty Seconds to Mars song)|Hurricane]]" (2010), which were both nominated for the [[MTV Video Music Award for Best Direction]].{{cite web|title=30 Seconds To Mars 'Amazed' By VMA Best Rock Video Win|first=James|last=Dinh|publisher=[[MTV]]. [[Viacom Media Networks]]|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1647660/30-seconds-to-mars-amazed-by-vma-best-rock-video-win/|date=September 12, 2010|accessdate=March 2, 2012}}{{cite web|title=30 Seconds To Mars Call VMA Nominations 'Humbling'|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1667688/30-seconds-to-mars-video-music-awards-nomination-reaction/|date=July 12, 2011|last=Montgomery|first=James|publisher=MTV. Viacom Media Networks|accessdate=March 28, 2014}} The latter garnered controversy upon release and was initially censored due to its elements of violence.{{cite web|last=Vick|first=Megan|title=30 Seconds To Mars Video Banned By MTV|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/30-seconds-mars-video-banned-54944|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=November 30, 2010|accessdate=March 28, 2014}} In 2012, Leto made his directorial debut with the documentary film ''[[Artifact (film)|Artifact]]''. After a six-year hiatus, he returned to film acting in the 2013 drama ''[[Dallas Buyers Club]]'' starring together with [[Matthew McConaughey]], for which he received the [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor]], [[Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actor – Motion Picture]], [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Supporting Role]] and a variety of film critics' circle awards.{{cite news|last1=Wang|first1=Andrea|title=Oscars 2014: Jared Leto wins supporting actor Academy Award|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/moviesnow/la-et-mn-oscars-2014-best-supporting-actor-story.html|accessdate=October 5, 2014|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=March 2, 2014}} Leto premiered the documentary series ''[[Into the Wild (TV series)|Into the Wild]]'' in 2014. He then played the [[Joker (character)|Joker]] in the superhero film ''[[Suicide Squad (film)|Suicide Squad]]'' (2016), which was unfavorably reviewed by critics, though Leto's performance received raves.{{cite news|last1=Khatchatourian|first1=Maane|title='Suicide Squad' Director Responds to Negative Reviews|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/suicide-squad-bad-reviews-director-responds-1201829629/|accessdate=January 3, 2017|work=Variety|date=August 3, 2016}} ==Films== {| class="wikitable" |+Key |style="background:#ffc;"|{{dagger}} |Indicates a film that has not yet been released |- |style="background:#add8e6"|{{double-dagger}} |Indicates a documentary |} {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="margin-right: 0;" |+ |- ! rowspan="2" scope="col" | Title ! rowspan="2" scope="col" | Year ! colspan="3" scope="col" | Credited as ! rowspan="2" scope="col" | Role ! rowspan="2" scope="col" class="unsortable" | Notes ! rowspan="2" scope="col" class="unsortable" | {{abbr|Refs.|Reference}} |- ! width=65 | Actor ! width=65 | Director ! width=65 | Producer |- ! scope="row" | ''[[How to Make an American Quilt]]'' | 1995 | {{yes}} | | | Beck | | style="text-align:center;" | {{cite news|last1=Klady|first1=Leonard|title=Review: 'How to Make an American Quilt'|url=https://variety.com/1995/film/reviews/how-to-make-an-american-quilt-1200443599/|accessdate=September 10, 2017|work=Variety|date=October 2, 1995}} |- ! scope="row" | ''{{sort|Last of the High Kings|[[The Last of the High Kings]]}}'' | 1996 | {{yes}} | | | {{sortname|Frankie|Griffin|nolink=yes}} | | style="text-align:center;" | {{cite web|url=http://www.allmovie.com/movie/the-last-of-the-high-kings-v136589|title=Summer Fling|first=Matthew|last=Tobey|publisher=[[AllMovie]]. Hildegarde Hawthorne | children = 2 | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = Willie Halsell College, [[Stanford University]] | genre = novel, biography | subject = Oklahoma, Texas, Native Americans | movement = | notableworks = }} '''John Milton Oskison''' (1874–1947) was a Native American author, editor and journalist. His fiction focused on the culture clash that mixed-bloods like himself faced. {{cite web|title=Native American History at Stanford|publisher=Stanford University|website=Native American Cultural Center|url=http://studentaffairs.stanford.edu/nacc/history}} ==Early life and career== Oskison was born the son of John (English) and Rachel Crittendon (part-Cherokee) Oskison in Cherokee Nation. He attended [[Willie Halsell College]]Actually, a high school. in [[Vinita, Oklahoma|Vinita]], where he met and befriended [[Will Rogers]]. Oskison was an undergraduate at Stanford, where he was president of the Stanford Literary Society. He graduated in 1898, and was Stanford's first Native American graduate. He attended Harvard for graduate school. But after one year, his short story "Only the Master Shall Praise" won a competition held by ''[[The Century Magazine]]'', and he became a professional writer. He became an editorial writer for the ''[[New York Evening Post]]''. He married Florence Ballard Day in 1903. In 1904 his short story "The Greater Appeal" won the Black Cat Prize. ==Later life and career== Oskison switched to ''[[Collier's Weekly]]'' in 1907, and became their financial editor in 1910. Oskison served with the [[American Expeditionary Force]] in World War I. In 1920, still in France, he and his wife divorced. On his return to the U. S., Oskison married [[Hildegarde Hawthorne]], a novelist.She was a granddaughter of [[Nathaniel Hawthorne]]: {{cite news|newspaper=The New York Times|date=1952-12-11|title=Mrs. H. H. Oskison, Novelist, is Dead|page=33|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/112258627}} He did not resume his position with ''Collier's'', but instead became an independent writer. Oskison wrote four novels, one novelized biography (of Sam Houston), one history with commentary (on Tecumseh), and part of an autobiography. During the Depression, he edited a WPA project on Oklahoma. At the time of his death, his fourth novel and his partial autobiography were in manuscript form only. His daughter donated Oskison's papers to the University of Oklahoma. His papers were rediscovered in 2007, and were subsequently published.{{cite book|chapter=Introduction|last1=Powell|first1=Timothy B.|last2=Mullikin|first2=Melinda Smith|editor-last=Oskison|editor-first=John Milton|title=The Singing Bird|page=xxii|year=2007|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|location=Norman, Oklahoma|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eqfhtZ0-NkIC&lpg=PR20&ots=cMe12tCxqP&pg=PR22#v=onepage&f=false}} ==Publications== *{{cite book|title=Wild Harvest|publisher=D. Appleton|year=1925}} *{{cite book|title=Black Jack Davy|publisher=D. Appleton|year=1926}} *{{cite book|title=Brothers Three|year=1935|publisher=Macmillan|url=http://hdl.handle.net/2027/uc1.$b57132}} *{{cite book|title=A Texan Titan: The Story of Sam Houston|year=1935|publisher=Doubleday}} *{{cite book|title=Tecumseh and his Times: The Story of a Great Indian|year=1938|publisher=G. B. Putnam's|url=http://hdl.handle.net/2027/uc1.$b59303}} *{{cite book|author=(edited, with Angie Debo)|title=Oklahoma: A Guide to the Sooner State|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|year=1941|url=https://archive.org/stream/oklahomaguidetos00writrich}} *{{cite book|editor1=Timothy B. Powell|editor2=Melinda Smith Mullikin|title=The Singing Bird|year=2007|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|isbn=978-0-8061-3818-3}} *{{cite book|editor=Lionel Larré|title=Tales of the Old Indian Territory and Essays on the Indian Condition|publisher=University of Nebraska Press|year=2012|isbn=978-0-8032-3792-6}} ==Tributes== In 1995, Stanford established the John Milton Oskison Writing Competition, held annually.{{cite web|title=2013 John Milton Oskison Writing Competition |publisher=Stanford University|website=Native American Cultural Center|url=http://studentaffairs.stanford.edu/nacc/history}} In 2008, a [[Oskison (crater)|crater]] on [[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]] was named after him.{{cite web|publisher=USGS Astrogeology Science Center|title=Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature|url=http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/Feature/14516}} ==External links== *{{cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/98970372|website=Find A Grave|title=John M. Oskison}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Oskison, John Milton}} [[Category:1874 births]] [[Category:1947 deaths]] [[Category:Stanford University alumni]] [[Category:Native American writers]] [[Category:Society of American Indians]] [[Category:Cherokee people]] [[Category:Collier's]] [[Category:American military personnel of World War I]]

'''Johnny Htoo''' and '''Luther Htoo''' (pronounced ''''too'''', 'H' is ''silent''; born circa 1988) are twin brothers who jointly led the [[God's Army (revolutionary group)|God's Army]] [[guerrilla warfare|guerrilla]] group — a splinter group of the [[Karen National Union]] — in [[Myanmar]] (Burma) during the late 1990s.
==Formation of God's Army (1997)== The Htoo twins were from an area of eastern Burma populated by the [[Karen people|Karen ethnic group]]. The Karen and Burmese army had fought at various times for over fifty years, but in the early 1990s the Burmese army launched a major operation to secure the route of an oil pipeline through the area. In March 1997, a local pastor brought the two illiterate nine-year-olds to the local military chief and said the Lord had spoken to them and they would save the Karen people.<ref name=guardian>{{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/g2/story/0,3604,347432,00.html | title = Two little boys | newspaper = The Guardian | date = 2000-07-27 | accessdate = 2012-01-16 | quote = The cameras found the students in the camp of the twins, who were nine years old at the time | location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.start.umd.edu/start/data_collections/tops/terrorist_organization_profile.asp?id=4032 | title = Terrorist Organization Profile: God's Army | publisher = [[National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism]] | accessdate = 2012-01-16 | quote = Johnny and Luther Htoo, twin brothers who were only nine years old when they formed the God's Army... }}</ref> According to the legend among followers, the twins then rallied defenders of their village by shouting "God's Army!", leading them to a victory over Burmese troops.<ref name=time>{{cite news | url = http://content.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2054474,00.html | title = The Twin Terrors | newspaper = Time | date = 2000-02-07 | accessdate = 2013-11-02}}</ref> Various legends claimed that the brothers had numerous magical powers, including invulnerability to bullets and [[land mine|mines]], and that they could hand out magical bullets. Supposedly, they could kill by pointing a rifle at the ground and concentrating. One tale claims that Johnny turned himself into an old man and back when bathing in a river. The legend of the boys was embraced by locals who viewed the existing Karen National Union as corrupt and ineffective. A new rebel group called God's Army of the Holy Mountain, or God's Army for short, was thus formed under the nominal leadership of the Htoo twins.<ref name=guardian />
==Worldwide attention (1999–2000)== God's Army was situated in mountainous rainforests along the border between Burma and [[Thailand]].<ref name=time /> They were a band of [[Christian]] guerrillas who maintained an austere lifestyle, including abstinence from sexual intercourse, alcohol, milk, eggs and pork. The boys, called "Bu Lu" and "Bu Joh" by their followers, were both [[Chain smoking|chain smokers]] and were said to know the Bible by heart although they had never studied it.
In October 1999, a group calling themselves Vigorous Burmese Student Warriors seized the Burmese embassy in [[Bangkok]] and the situation ended with their departure, at which point they were taken in by God's Army.<ref name=nytimes>{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2001/01/17/world/17THAI.html | title = Burmese Rebel Twins and 14 Followers Surrender in Thailand | newspaper = NY Times | date = 2001-01-17 | accessdate = 2013-11-02}}</ref>
The Htoos came to worldwide attention in January 2000 when 10 members of God's Army seized a hospital in [[Ratchaburi]], Thailand.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/pmextra/jan00/24/hostage.htm | work=The Washington Post | title= Child Terrorists Hold Hundreds Hostage in Thailand | date=2000-01-24}}</ref> The group held 700 to 800 patients and staff members [[hostage]] for 22 hours. They demanded the Thai government stop shelling Karen positions in Burma and treatment for their wounded. Thai security forces stormed the hospital, killing all 10 of the gunmen.<ref name=time /> A photograph taken by Associated Press photographer Apichart Weerawong of a long-haired Johnny posing next to his tougher-looking, cigar-puffing brother was circulated around the world after the hospital raid. After the raid, God's Army were strenuously pursued by the [[Tatmadaw]] (Burmese armed forces) and shunned by other Karen rebels. Luther claimed at the time he had 250,000 invisible soldiers in his command while Johnny had 150,000 of his own. Their flesh-and-blood followers was estimated to be around 500 in 1998, but gradually declined to between 100 and 200 men by early 2000 after many left to find work to support their refugee families. Meanwhile, the Burmese army had 21,000 troops in the area.<ref name=nytimes2>{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2000/04/10/world/burmese-rebel-chief-more-boy-than-warrior.html | title = Burmese Rebel Chief More Boy Than Warrior | newspaper = NY Times | date = 2000-04-01 | accessdate = 2013-11-02 | first=Seth | last=Mydans}}</ref>
==Surrender and life after God's Army (2001– )== The twins surrendered to Thai soldiers in January 2001 and requested sanctuary. By that time the number of their followers had dwindled to less than 20.<ref name=nytimes /> They repudiated the stories about being invulnerable but insisted that God had helped them to survive over the years. They were reunited with their family. In July 2006, Johnny Htoo surrendered in Burma's military government with eight other members of God's Army in two groups.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/sunbin/stories/w-asia/2006/jul/25/072500407.html |title=Myanmar Teen Rebel Leader Surrenders|date=2006-07-25|publisher=Las Vegas Sun|accessdate=2009-09-14 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080104152815/http://www.lasvegassun.com/sunbin/stories/w-asia/2006/jul/25/072500407.html |archivedate = 2008-01-04}}</ref>
Luther Htoo now lives in Sweden.<ref>[http://www.aljazeera.com/video/asia-pacific/2013/09/201391541541502909.html Myanmar's rebels recount tales of horror]</ref> Johnny Htoo lives in a Thai refugee camp and has been attempting to go to New Zealand to join his mother and sister.<ref>[http://www.boston.com/news/world/asia/2013/11/01/myanmar-god-army-twins-reunite-seek-comrades/GoRUrEPDts23ShT2N6iVgO/story-1.html Myanmar 'God's Army' twins reunite, seek comrades] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103182227/http://www.boston.com/news/world/asia/2013/11/01/myanmar-god-army-twins-reunite-seek-comrades/GoRUrEPDts23ShT2N6iVgO/story-1.html |date=November 3, 2013 }}</ref>

'''Jonathan Martin''' (1782– 3 June 1838) was an English [[arsonist]], famous for setting fire to [[York Minster]] in 1829.
==Early life== Martin was born at Highside House, near [[Hexham]] in Northumberland, one of the twelve children of William Fenwick Martin and Isabella, ''née'' Thompson. Among his siblings was the artist [[John Martin (painter)|John Martin]] and the philosopher [[William Martin (philosopher)|William Martin]]. Jonathan was [[tongue tied]] and spoke with an [[speech impediment|impediment]]. He was brought up by his aunt, Ann Thompson, a staunch Protestant with a vivid image of hell.
After he witnessed the murder of his sister by a neighbour, he was sent to his uncle's farm to recover from the shock. He was apprenticed to a [[Tanning (leather)|tanner]] but was [[Impressment|press ganged]] in London in 1804. He served in the [[Royal Navy]] ship [[HMS Hercule (1798)|HMS ''Hercule'']] for six years, including the [[Battle of Copenhagen (1807)|Battle of Copenhagen]] in 1807. He was noted among his shipmates for his religious obsession.
He left the Navy when his ship was broken up in 1810, returning to [[Norton, County Durham]], where he married, and his son Richard was born in 1814. After his parents died, he became a [[Methodist Church of Great Britain|Wesleyan]] preacher in 1814, strongly denouncing the [[Church of England]]. He gained a reputation for disrupting church services.
After threatening to shoot the [[Bishop of Oxford]], [[Edward Legge (bishop)|Edward Legge]] at a confirmation service in [[Stockton-on-Tees|Stockton]] in 1817, he was arrested, tried, and was sent to a private [[lunatic asylum]] in [[West Auckland]]. He was later moved to the public asylum in [[Gateshead]]. He escaped in June 1820, but was soon recaptured.
His wife died of breast cancer in 1821, and he escaped from the asylum for a second time, returning to work as a [[Tanning (leather)|tanner]] and preacher. The Wesleyan Church refused to take him back, and he was turned away by the [[Primitive Methodism|Primitive Methodists]]. He published his autobiography at [[Lincoln, Lincolnshire|Lincoln]] in 1826, with further editions published in 1828, 1829 and 1830, and he made a living by selling his book.
==Arson== He remarried in [[Boston, Lincolnshire]] in 1828, to Maria Hudson, and the couple moved to [[York]].
A year later, Martin had another mental breakdown. On Sunday 1 February 1829, he became upset by a buzzing sound in the [[Organ (music)|organ]] while attending [[Evening Prayer (Anglican)|evensong]] at [[York Minster]]. He hid in the building, and then lit a lamp in the belltower. The cathedral watchman had been discharged, and the light was ignored by anyone who saw it. Later that night, he set fire to the woodwork in the [[choir]] before escaping through a window. Smoke was seen coming out of the building at 7am on 2 February, and the fire was raging through the organ and choir by 8am. The fire was brought under control that afternoon and extinguished on 3 February, when the extent of the damage became apparent. A section of the roof of the central aisle approximately {{convert|131|foot}} long was destroyed, stretching from the lantern tower towards the east window, together with much of the internal woodwork from the organ screen to the altar screen, including the organ, medieval choir stalls, the bishop's throne, and the pulpit. The cause – arson – soon became apparent, and the culprit was identified from threatening placards Martin had left on the Minster railings in previous days, including his initials and address.
Martin was captured near Hexham on 6 February. He was tried at [[York Castle]] in March 1829, before [[baron of the exchequer|Baron]] [[John Hullock|Hullock]] and a jury. The case was a national cause célèbre, coming only two months after the trials of [[Burke and Hare]] in Edinburgh. Martin was defended by [[Henry Brougham, 1st Baron Brougham and Vaux|Henry Brougham]], who had gained notoriety for defending [[Caroline of Brunswick|Queen Caroline]] in 1821. Despite the jury ruling that he was guilty on a capital charge, which should have resulted in a death sentence, the judge declared him not guilty on the grounds of insanity. He was detained in [[Bethlem Royal Hospital]], where he remained until he died 9 years later. During this period of detention, he made a number of drawings, including self-portraits and an apocalyptic picture of the destruction of London. His son, Richard, from his first marriage, was brought up by Jonathan's brother [[John Martin (painter)|John]]. Richard committed suicide in September 1838, three months after his father's death.
Professor [[Herschel Prins]] has described Martin as "probably the most well-known example of a [[manic depressive]] arsonist".

{{Spanish name 2|Cardenal|Nicolau}} '''Juan Pablo Cardenal Nicolau''' ([[Barcelona]], 1968) is a Spanish journalist and writer.<ref>[http://www.planetadelibros.com/juan-pablo-cardenal-nicolau-autor-000038813.html Bio of Juan P. Cardenal] {{es icon}}</ref>
He resides in [[Hong Kong]] where he works as a [[correspondent]] for the Spanish business newspaper ''[[El Economista (Spain)|El Economista]]''. His research about Chinese affairs in the world has attracted international recognition.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.americasquarterly.org/la-silenciosa-conquista-china |publisher=[[Americas Quarterly]] |title=The Silent Chinese Conquest|accessdate=25 November 2013 }}</ref>

{{Infobox YouTube personality | name = Ken Nwadike Jr. | image = Ken-E-Nwadike-Jr-motivational-speaker.jpg | alt = Free Hugs Guy | caption = Nwadike in 2017 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1981|12|29}} | birth_place = [[San Diego, California]], United States | occupation = {{plainlist| * [[Motivational speaking|Inspirational Speaker]] * [[Filmmaking|Filmmaker]] * [[Activism|Activist]] }} | website = {{URL|FreeHugsProject.com}} | pseudonym = Free Hugs Guy | genre = {{flatlist| * [[Motivational speaking|Motivation]] * [[Random Acts of Kindness]] * [[Social Justice]] }} | subscribers = 106,329 subscribers | subscriber_date = 23rd November 2018 | views = 8.41 million views | view_date = 23rd November 2018 | network = [[Studio 71|Studio71]] | associated_acts = | silver_year = 2018 | years_active= 2014–Present | silver_button = yes }} '''Kenneth E. "Ken" Nwadike Jr.''' is an American [[Documentary film|documentary]] [[Filmmaking|filmmaker]], [[Motivational speaking|motivational speaker]], and [[peace activist]] popularly known as the '''Free Hugs Guy'''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Man Offers Hugs At Trump And Sanders Rallies, Asks Which America We Want|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/free-hugs-project-bernie-trump-rally-video_us_56fc40eee4b083f5c606a4ff|website=The Huffington Post|accessdate=31 March 2016|date=31 March 2016}} </ref> Ken is the founder of the '''Free Hugs Project'''. His "Free Hugs" videos have reached hundreds of millions of views on [[Facebook]] and [[YouTube]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Deaderick |first=Lisa |date=7 May 2016 |title=Making the world better, a hug at a time |url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/2016/may/07/ken-nwadike-free-hugs-project/ |newspaper=The San Diego Union-Tribune |location= |accessdate=8 May 2016 }}</ref>
==Career== In 2014, Nwadike launched the Free Hugs Project to spread love in response to the bombing of the Boston Marathon. The Free Hugs Project gained popularity in 2016, as Nwadike made major news headlines for his peacekeeping efforts and de-escalation of violence during protests, riots, and political rallies.<ref>{{cite news |last=Peterson |first=Karla |date=31 October 2016 |title=In failing the homeless, San Diego stands apart |url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/lifestyle/people/sd-me-ken-hugs-20161011-htmlstory.html |newspaper=The San Diego Union-Tribune |location= |accessdate=31 October 2016 }}</ref> Nwadike was featured in Google's 2016 Year in Search video as a highlight among some of the year's most defining moments.<ref>{{cite news |last=Tremelling |first=Miriam |date=21 December 2016 |title=Google's 'Year in Search 2016' connects with message of hope |url=http://www.campaignlive.com/article/googles-year-search-2016-connects-message-hope/1419337 |newspaper=Campaign US |location= |accessdate=21 December 2016 }}</ref> Nwadike has made many appearances on news programs and radio broadcasts worldwide, including CNN, USA Today, Good Morning Britain, and BBC News.
Nwadike is the President and CEO of Superhero Events, LLC, which produces the annual [[Hollywood Half Marathon]]. The marathon, held each spring in [[Hollywood]], [[California]] to raise funds for local homeless youth shelters.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hollywood Half Marathon|url=http://www.nbclosangeles.com/the-scene/events/Hollywood-Half-Marathon-146201025.html|website=NBC Los Angeles|accessdate=5 April 2012|date=5 April 2012}}</ref>
On March 30, 2016, Nwadike released the controversial "Donald Trump Rally Free Hugs vs Bernie Sanders Rally Free Hugs" video to his "Free Hugs Project" channels on YouTube, Facebook and Twitter.<ref>{{cite web|title=Free Hugs Project shows difference between Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump rallies|url=http://www.amny.com/news/elections/free-hugs-project-shows-difference-between-bernie-sanders-and-donald-trump-rallies-1.11639468|website=AM New York|accessdate=31 March 2016|date=31 March 2016}}</ref> The video became a viral hit and his #MakeAmericaLoveAgain hashtag became a trending topic on Facebook and Twitter.<ref>{{cite web|title=Here's What Happens When You Ask for a Hug at a Trump Rally Versus a Sanders Rally|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/heres-happens-ask-hug-trump-193100859.html|website=Yahoo News|accessdate=2 April 2016|date=2 April 2016}}</ref> Nwadike's "Free Hugs" videos have reached hundreds of millions of views on [[Facebook]] and [[YouTube]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Deaderick |first=Lisa |date=7 May 2016 |title=Making the world better, a hug at a time |url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/2016/may/07/ken-nwadike-free-hugs-project/ |newspaper=The San Diego Union-Tribune |location= |accessdate=8 May 2016 }}</ref>
===Motivational speaker=== As a motivational speaker, Ken details his former homelessness and states that he overcame insecurities by getting involved in extracurricular activities in school. The support, he says, he received from coaches, teammates, and friends while playing sports and participating in student government activities, helped pave the way for Ken to start a number of businesses and a charitable organization that helps homeless teens.<ref>{{cite web|title=Peace Activist / Motivational Speaker|url=http://www.freehugsproject.com/motivational-speaker/|website=Free Hugs Project|accessdate=1 October 2016|date=1 October 2016}}</ref>
The Free Hugs Project is a program conducted at workplaces and colleges. Nwadike converses with students and employees during small group discussions. His visit concludes with a keynote address. He has stated that his program intends to promote unity, civility and to bridge the racial divide and to build a more diverse and inclusive culture.<ref>{{cite web|title=Peace Activist / Motivational Speaker|url=http://www.freehugsproject.com/motivational-speaker/|website=Free Hugs Project|accessdate=1 October 2016|date=1 October 2016}}</ref>
In October 2017, Nwadike filed with the [[Federal Election Commission]] to run for [[President of the United States]] in the [[United States presidential election, 2020|2020 election]], seeking the nomination of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://docquery.fec.gov/pdf/394/201710190300178394/201710190300178394.pdf|title=FEC FORM 2|date=October 18, 2017|first=Kenneth E.|last=Nwadike|work=[[Federal Election Commission]]|accessdate=July 31, 2018}}</ref>
==Live appearances== Aside from YouTube and Facebook videos, Nwadike has appeared on worldwide news programs and radio broadcasts. * April 4, 2012 - Nwadike was featured on an [[NBC 4 Los Angeles]] special, titled, Life Connected.<ref>{{cite web|title=Formerly Homeless Man Directs Race to Benefit Local Shelters|url=http://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/local/Hollywood-Marathon-Homeless-Shelters--146030615.html|website=NBC 4 Los Angeles|accessdate=4 April 2012|date=4 April 2012}}</ref> * April 5, 2016 - Nwadike interview with [[Pix 11]] news to share why he launched the Free Hugs Project.<ref>{{cite web|title=‘Free Hugs’ man wants to make America LOVE again with free hugs|url=https://www.facebook.com/AndrewRamosTV/videos/501945523330323/|website=Pix 11 News New York|accessdate=5 April 2016|date=5 April 2016}}</ref> * March 23, 2016 - Free Hugs Guy interviewed live on set during the [[Fox 5 San Diego]] morning show to discuss the Free Hugs Project and give hugs to news anchors.<ref>{{cite web|title=‘Free Hugs’ guy brings project to San Diego|url=http://fox5sandiego.com/2016/05/23/free-hugs-man-brings-project-to-san-diego/|website=Fox 5 San Diego|accessdate=23 May 2016|date=23 May 2016}}</ref> * September 16, 2016 - Ken teams up with the hosts of Good Morning Britain in London to launch Free Hugs Friday.<ref>{{cite web|title=Time to celebrate Free Hugs Friday!|url=http://www.itv.com/goodmorningbritain/entertainment/time-to-celebrate-free-hugs-friday|website=ITV Good Morning Britain|accessdate=16 September 2016|date=16 September 2016}}</ref> * September 23, 2016 - Nwadike was interviewed live on CNN with Poppy Harlow after Charlotte Protests. <ref>{{cite web|title=Activist hands out 'Free Hugs' amid violent protests in Charlotte|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/09/22/us/ken-nwadike-free-hugs-poppy-harlow-cnn-newsroom/|website=CNN |accessdate=23 September 2016|date=23 September 2016}}</ref>
