Abdülhamid Han Ailesi|title=Kadınefendiler: Son Dönem Osmanlı Padişah Eşleri|language=Turkish|edition=1|location=Istanbul|publisher=Prolil Yayıncılık|page=32|access-date=24 Apr 2016}} (modern-day Russia) or [[Armenia]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1852|10|3|1819|8|16|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Feriye Palace]], [[Istanbul]], [[Ottoman Empire]] | burial_place = Cedid Havatin [[Türbe]], [[New Mosque (Istanbul)|New Mosque]], Istanbul | spouse = [[Abdülmecid I]] | issue = Naime Sultan
[[Abdul Hamid II]]
Şehzade Mehmed Abid | house = | father = Bekhan Bey | mother = Almaş Hanım | religion = [[Armenian Apostolic Church|Apostolic Christianity]] , converted later to [[Islam]] }} '''Tirimüjgan Kadın'''Freely, John – ''Inside the Seraglio'', Chapter 15: On the Shores of the Bosphorus, published 1999, Istanbul) (16 August 1819 – 3 October 1852; {{lang-ota|تیرمژکان قادین}}) was a consort of Sultan [[Abdülmecid I]] of the [[Ottoman Empire]].{{cite web|url =http://www.osmanli.org.tr/osmanlisultanlari-5-243.html|title=Ottoman Research Foundation (in Turkish); announces the results of their recent investigations and proclaims her name as "Tîr-î-Müjgan Kadın Efendi"|accessdate=17 December 2010|work=Ottoman Sultans Web Page}} and the mother of Sultan [[Abdul Hamid II]].{{cite web|url=http://www.kultur.gov.tr/EN/belge/2-1305/sultan-ii-abdulhamid-han.html|title=Sultan Abdülhamid II Khan | accessdate=17 December 2010|work=Ministry of Culture and Tourism}} ==Early life== According to some sources, Tirimüjgan Kadınefendi was [[Armenians|Armenian]].{{cite book|author=John Freely|title=Inside the Seraglio: private lives of the sultans in Istanbul|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Za0TAQAAIAAJ|date=1 July 2001|publisher=Penguin}} According to others Tirimüjgan Kadınefendi was born in historical [[Circassia]] in the [[Caucasus]] (present-day western Russia), and belonged to the [[Shapsugs|Shapsug]] tribe of the [[Circassians]]. Her father was Bekhan [[Bey]] and her mother was Almaş [[Khanum|Hanım]]. She was given the name "Tirimüjgan" in the Ottoman Empire. She was among the longest serving kalfas at the palace for her refinement, her politeness, and her beauty. In her memoirs, Ayşe Sultan, the daughter of Sultan Abdul Hamid II, depicts Tirimüjgan Kadınefendi as having "green eyes and long, dark blond hair, pale skin of translucent white colour, thin waist, slender body structure, and very good-looking hands and feet." Ayşe Sultan adds that "Old Circassian women at the palace used to tell that she [Tirimüjgan] was from the Shapsug tribe, and I also remember my father [Abdul Hamid II] referring to every Shapsug Adyghe [Circassian] girl as "Our Valide's (''mother'') kind". Despite her well-documented origins, Abdülhamid II's personal enemies falsely claimed that she was the daughter of an Armenian musician, originally named Çandır. ==Marriage== Tirimüjgan married Abdülmecid in 1839 at the [[Topkapı Palace]] in [[Istanbul]]. She gave birth to two princes and one princess. Her first child was Princess Naime Sultan, who died of [[smallpox]] at the age of two and a half in March 1843. Sultan [[Abdul Hamid II]] was her second child, while her third child was Şehzade Mehmed Abid Efendi, who died in May 1848 around the age of one month.Yavuz Bahadıroğlu, Resimli Osmanlı Tarihi, Nesil Yayınları ''(Ottoman History with Illustrations, Nesil Publications)'', 15th Ed., 2009, p. 505, {{ISBN|978-975-269-299-2}} Whenever Sultan Abdülhamid II would speak of his mother, he would say: "My poor mother left this world at such a young age, but I can still picture her. I can never forget her. She loved me very much. When she became ill, she used to have me sit opposite her and content herself with gazing into my face, for she could not bring herself to kiss me. May God bless her soul."{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} ==Death== Tirimüjgan Kadınefendi died of [[tuberculosis]] on 3 October 1852 at the [[Feriye Palace]] in [[Istanbul]]. She died nearly 23 years before Sultan Abdul Hamid II's accession to the Ottoman throne on 31 August 1876. In place of his biological mother Tirimüjgan Kadınefendi, the title of [[Valide Sultan]] was acquired by [[Perestu Kadın]] who was the adoptive mother of [[Abdul Hamid II]]. Her tomb is located inside the royal mausoleum of imperial ladies at the [[New Mosque (Istanbul)|Yeni Mosque]] in [[Istanbul]]. In 1887, her son Abdul Hamid II built a mosque in her memory. ==See also== *[[List of consorts of the Ottoman Sultans]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Abdul Hamid II}} {{Mothers of the Ottoman Sultans}} {{Ottoman Dynasty}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tirimujgan Sultan}} [[Category:1819 births]] [[Category:1852 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century people of the Ottoman Empire]] [[Category:Abdul Hamid II]] [[Category:People of the Ottoman Empire of Circassian descent]] [[Category:People of the Ottoman Empire of Armenian descent]] [[Category:Wives of Ottoman Sultans]]

Valley''' or ('''Dare''-ye'' Turkman''', {{lang-prs|درهٔ ترکمن}}, {{lang-haz|درهٔ تورکمون}}) is a valley in [[Afghanistan]] located in [[Surkhi Parsa District]] of [[Parwan Province]] which is web|url=https://www.google.com/maps/d/viewer?mid=zVwTv9eN5lLI.kvUrg-iqOtl8&hl=en_US|title=Dareturkman|website=www.google.com|access-date=2017-06-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite == Etymology == The name of this valley is derived from the [[Turkmun (Hazara tribe)|Turkmani]], one of the [[Hazara tribes|tribes]] of the [[Hazara people]].<ref name=":0" />
== Demographics == The population of the Turkman valley is generally composed of the Turkmen Hazara tribe.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.afghanistanema.com/index/%D8%AA%D8%B1%DA%A9%D9%85%D9%86-%D8%AF%D8%B1%D9%87-%D8%AF%D8%B1-%D9%BE%D8%B1%D9%88%D8%A7%D9%86/|title=ترکمن دره در پروان|last=|first=|work=افغانستان ما|access-date=2018-05-22|language=fa-IR}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} [[Image:Poster for Emerald Isle.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Poster from ''[[The Emerald Isle]]'']][[Image:Cover of the Vocal Score of Seymour Hicks' The Earl and the Girl.jpg|thumb|Cover of vocal score of ''[[The Earl and the Girl]]'']] '''William Greet''' (1851 – 25 April 1914) was a British theatre manager from the end of the 19th century and into the 20th century. Originally a business manager for other theatre licensees in the 1880s, he branched out as an independent manager in the 1890s and was associated with various London theatres, principally the [[Lyric Theatre (London)|Lyric]], the [[Savoy Theatre|Savoy]] and the [[Adelphi Theatre]]s.
==Biography== Greet was the seventh child and eldest son of Captain Wiliam Greet [[Royal Navy|R.N.]], commander of the recruiting ship H.M.S. Crocodile, and the former Sarah Vallance Barling. Greet's younger brother was the actor-manager [[Ben Greet]]. Greet was born on his father's ship, christened at [[Church of St Peter ad Vincula|St Peter ad Vincula]] at the [[Tower of London]], and educated at the [[Royal Naval School]], [[New Cross]]. He served as a Lieutenant of the [[Royal Marine Artillery]] from 1871 to 1877.
===Career=== He worked first as a farmer and then began working in theatre management in the 1880s.<ref>[http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~pnlowe/egerton/g0000006.html#I342 William Greet] at Rootsweb</ref> Between 1884 and 1890, Greet was successively business manager at the [[Folly Theatre|Toole's Theatre]] under its licensee, [[J. L. Toole]],<ref>''[[The Observer]]'', 28 December 1884, p. 4</ref> the [[Novelty Theatre]] (licensee, [[Willie Edouin]]),<ref>''[[The Times]]'', 22 November 1885, p. 8</ref> the [[Royalty Theatre]] (licensee, [[Kate Santley]]),<ref>[http://www.bl.uk/catalogues/evanion/FullImage.aspx?EvanID=024-000001699&ImageId=50659 British Library catalogues]</ref> the [[Scala Theatre|Prince of Wales's Theatre]] (licensee, Horace Sedger),<ref>''The Times'', 23 January 1888, p. 8</ref> and from 1890 to 1894 the [[Lyric Theatre (London)|Lyric Theatre]], also for Sedger, with whom Greet's wife collaborated on a stage adaptation of the novel ''The Little Squire''.<ref>''The Times'', 9 October 1890 and 6 April 1894</ref>
Greet became a producer and theatre manager in his own right in 1894, as licensee of the [[Playhouse Theatre|Avenue Theatre]], starting successfully with the long-running ''[[Dandy Dick Whittington]]'' by [[George R. Sims]] and [[Ivan Caryll]]<ref>''The Times'', 12 November 1894, p. 8</ref> and a popular comedy by [[F. C. Burnand]], ''Mrs Ponderbury's Past'' (later billed as ''Mrs Ponderbury''), directed by and starring [[Charles Hawtrey (stage actor)|Charles Hawtrey]].<ref>''The Times'', 4 November 1895 and 2 March 1896</ref> In 1896, Greet gave up the licence at the Avenue and moved to the Lyric, where he presented the long-running ''The Sign of the Cross'' by [[Wilson Barrett]], also producing an American tour of the play.<ref>''The Times'' 29 August 1896, p. 6</ref> He followed that success with another, ''Dandy Dan the Lifeguardsman'' by [[Basil Hood]] and [[Walter Slaughter]], starring [[Arthur Roberts (comedian)|Arthur Roberts]] and [[W. H. Denny]].<ref>''The Times'' 6 January 1898, p. 6</ref> Greet sat on the Board of Directors of The Lyceum Theatre Ltd. from 1899 until 1902.<ref name=irving>[http://www.theirvingsociety.org.uk/landlord.htm The Irving Society]</ref>
In 1901, Greet leased the [[Savoy Theatre]] from [[Helen Carte]], the widow of [[Richard D'Oyly Carte]]. He then managed the [[D'Oyly Carte Opera Company]]'s revival of ''[[Iolanthe]]'' at the Savoy and its production of several new [[comic opera]]s including ''[[The Emerald Isle]]'', ''[[Merrie England (opera)|Merrie England]]'' (1902) and ''[[A Princess of Kensington]]'' (1903), both at the Savoy and on tour. At the same time, he also leased the [[Lyric Theatre (London)|Lyric Theatre]] in London, producing ''Mice and Men'' in 1902, ''The Light that Failed'' in 1903 and [[Edwardian musical comedy|the musical comedies]] ''The Medal and the Maid'' (1903), and ''[[The Duchess of Dantzic]]'' (1904). He also leased the [[Comedy Theatre]] in London, where he produced the hit musicals ''[[Monsieur Beaucaire (operetta)|Monsieur Beaucaire]]'' and ''[[Morocco Bound]]'', both in 1902.
Greet continued to produce musical comedies and operettas, many of them very successful, including ''[[The Earl and the Girl]]'' at the [[Adelphi Theatre]] (1903), ''The Talk of the Town'' (1905, Lyric Theatre), ''Blue Moon'' (1905, Lyric), ''The Sign of the Cross'' (Terriss Theatre), ''[[Alice in Wonderland (musical)|Alice in Wonderland]]'' (1908), ''A White Man'' (1908, Lyric), ''Little Hans Andersen'' (1909, by [[Basil Hood]]), ''The Fires of Fate'' (1909, Lyric), ''The Rivals'' (1910, Lyric), ''[[The Chocolate Soldier]]'' (1910, Lyric), ''Baby Mine'' (1911, [[Vaudeville Theatre]]), ''Nightbirds'' (1911, Lyric), and ''[[The Girl in the Taxi]]'' (1912, Lyric).
Greet died in [[Bournemouth]] at the age of 62 and was buried at [[Shillingford]].<ref>[http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.com/~pnlowe/egerton/g0000002.html#I342 Rootsweb]</ref>

{{Redirect-distinguish|Vintner|Vinter (disambiguation)}} {{For|the PBS television series|The Winemakers}} {{For|the surname|Vinther}} A '''winemaker''' or '''vintner''' is a person engaged in [[winemaking]]. They are generally employed by [[winery|wineries]] or [[:Category:Wine companies|wine companies]], where their work includes: *Cooperating with [[viticulture|viticulturist]]s *Monitoring the maturity of grapes to ensure their quality and to determine the correct time for harvest *Crushing and [[pressing (wine)|pressing]] grapes *Monitoring the settling of [[grape juice|juice]] and the fermentation of grape material *[[filter (chemistry)|Filtering]] the wine to remove remaining solids *Testing the quality of wine by [[wine tasting|tasting]] *Placing filtered wine in [[casks]] or tanks for [[storage (wine)|storage]] and maturation *Preparing plans for bottling wine once it has matured *Making sure that quality is maintained when the wine is bottled<ref>Echikson, Tom. ''Noble Rot''. NY: Norton, 2004</ref>
Today, these duties require an increasing amount of scientific knowledge, since laboratory tests are gradually supplementing or replacing traditional methods. Winemakers can also be referred to as oenologists as they study [[oenology]] – the science of wine.
==Vintner== [[File:Grapes.jpg|300px|thumb|right|Wine grapes.]] A vintner is a [[wine]] [[merchant]]. In some modern use, particularly in [[American English]], the term is also used as a synonym for winemaker.<ref name=OCW-vint/>
The term started in [[Middle English]], superseding the earlier term ''vinter''.<ref name=OCW-vint/>
Due to the close political and commercial ties between [[Bordeaux wine|Bordeaux]] and England during the 14th and early 15th centuries, vintners were among the more important people in [[London]] with winemakers being four times mayor of the city under the reign of [[Edward II of England|Edward II]].<ref name="OCW-vint">{{cite encyclopedia |editor=[[Jancis Robinson]] | encyclopedia=[[Oxford Companion to Wine]] |edition= Third |title=Vintner |year=2006 |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=Oxford |isbn=0-19-860990-6 |page=754 }}</ref>
==Vigneron== A vigneron is someone who cultivates a [[vineyard]] for winemaking. The word connotes or emphasizes the critical role that vineyard placement and maintenance has in the production of high-quality wine.<ref>[http://www.vinsdebandol.com/en/savoir-faire.html The Vigneron's Savoir-Faire: The Result of Commitment] from the website of the Association les VINS de Bandol</ref> The term, French for someone who grows grapes or makes wine,<ref>[http://www.larousse.com/en/dictionaries/french/vigneron]{{dead link|date=February 2018}}</ref> is often used in Australia to describe a winemaker who is also involved as an owner or manager<ref>[http://www.consumer.vic.gov.au/CA256EB5000644CE/page/Liquor-Types+of+Licences-Vignerons+Licence?OpenDocument&1=75-Liquor~&2=010-Types+of+Licences~&3=090-Vignerons+Licence~ Vignerons Licence] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091016113504/http://www.consumer.vic.gov.au/CA256EB5000644CE/page/Liquor-Types+of+Licences-Vignerons+Licence?OpenDocument&1=75-Liquor~&2=010-Types+of+Licences~&3=090-Vignerons+Licence~ |date=2009-10-16 }} from a [[Government of Victoria (Australia)|Government of Victoria]] website</ref><ref>[http://www.farmonline.com.au/winemags/grapegrowersvignerons/index.aspx ''GrapeGrowers & Vignerons''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090914161857/http://www.farmonline.com.au/WineMags/grapegrowersvignerons/index.aspx |date=2009-09-14 }} magazine</ref><ref>[http://www.miettas.com.au/food_wine_recipes/wine/wine_articles/kingvalley.html King Valley] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091119093351/http://www.miettas.com.au/food_wine_recipes/wine/wine_articles/kingvalley.html |date=2009-11-19 }} from Mietta's Guide to Australian Restaurant, Cafes & Bars</ref> as opposed to a person who is employed only to make wine, who is generally referred to as a winemaker. It is also used when referring to a winemaker from France.<ref>[http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/lifestyles/fooddrink/winecellar/s_553191.html Vigneron discusses what makes great wine]{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} from the ''[[Pittsburgh Tribune-Review]]''</ref><ref>[http://us.ft.com/ftgateway/superpage.ft?news_id=fto051220080021293510&page=1 Brits who love a vigneron's life]{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} from the ''[[Financial Times]]''</ref>
[[Vincent of Saragossa]] is the [[patron saint]] of vignerons.
==Négociant== A '''''négociant''''' is the [[French language|French]] term for a [[wine]] merchant who assembles the produce of smaller growers and winemakers and sells the result under its own name.<ref name="OCW-neg">{{Cite web |last= ''Oxford Companion to Wine'' |title= Negociant |url= http://www.winepros.com.au/jsp/cda/reference/oxford_entry.jsp?entry_id=2184 |deadurl= yes| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20131110160323/http://www.winepros.com.au/jsp/cda/reference/oxford_entry.jsp?entry_id=2184 |archivedate= 2013-11-10|df= }}</ref>
Négociants buy everything from [[grape]]s to grape [[must]] to wines in various states of completion. In the case of grapes or must, the ''négociant'' performs virtually all the [[wine-making|winemaking]]. If he buys already fermented wine in barrels or ''en-vrac''—basically in bulk containers, he may [[age the wine]] further, blend in other wines or simply bottle and sell it as is. The result is sold under the name of the ''négociant'', not the name of the original grape or wine producer.
Some ''négociants'' have a recognizable house style.
''Négociants'', who are also called wine merchants/traders, were the dominant force in the wine trade until the last 25 years for various reasons: * Historically the owners of vineyards and producers of wine had no direct access to buyers. * It was too expensive for growers to purchase the [[Fruit press|wine presses]] and [[bottling line]]s necessary to produce a finished wine. * Owning only a small portion of a particular high-quality single vineyard (''[[lieu-dit]]'') meant that a grower often had insufficient wine from a parcel to vinify on its own. Under French inheritance laws, vineyard holdings were often split until offspring owned no more than a single row of grapes, not enough to fill a [[barrel]]. Since prices for a ''[[premier cru]]'' are typically higher than for wines from a larger area like a village or region, the grower could make more money selling off the production as the ''premier cru'' rather than blending it into a less specific appellation.
Many ''négociants'' are also vineyard owners in their own right. In [[Burgundy wine|Burgundy]] for instance, ''négociants'' as [[Bouchard Père et Fils]] and [[Faiveley (winery)|Faiveley]] are among the largest owners of vineyards.<ref name=OCW-neg/> Well-known ''négociants'' in Burgundy are [[Maison Louis Jadot]], [[Joseph Drouhin]], and [[Vincent Girardin]]; in Beaujolais, [[Georges Duboeuf]]; in Province, Mirabeau<ref>[http://www.mirabeauwine.com/ mirabeauwine.com]</ref>; and in the [[Rhône (wine region)|Rhône]] region, [[Guigal]], [[Jaboulet]], [[Jean-Luc Colombo]], [[Chapoutier]], and [[Famille Perrin]]''.
